parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name or any other identifying information. It mentions candidates in general terms, asking about the public's perception of them.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid Facebook advertisement targeting a wide geographical area (Botoșani County and surrounding areas) and age range (primarily older demographics), clearly aiming for broad public reach.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>Potentially True, but inconclusive. While the post asks about voter preferences and mentions the upcoming parliamentary elections, it doesn't explicitly endorse or discourage voting for any particular candidate or party.  The objective could be interpreted as gauging public opinion for journalistic purposes, or it could be subtly influencing voters by highlighting the election and prompting reflection on candidate choices.  The ambiguity leans towards "inconclusive" given the "in dubio pro reo" principle.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>Potentially True. The post's phrasing suggests an attempt to gather public opinion on candidates, which could be considered a form of journalistic inquiry. However, the lack of clear journalistic standards (e.g., balanced reporting, fact-checking) makes this interpretation uncertain.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; instead, it poses questions to the public, aiming to collect data on their views.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>936192708420591</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post is ambiguous. While it mentions the upcoming parliamentary elections and asks about voter preferences, it doesn't explicitly endorse or oppose any candidate.  The targeting is broad, and the content could be interpreted as opinion polling for journalistic purposes. However, the potential for subtle influence on voter choices exists, making a definitive classification difficult.  Given the "in dubio pro reo" principle, the evidence is insufficient to definitively label it as electoral propaganda.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Vocea - Botosani</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
